short_description: Regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting
laymans_description: This technology is an industrial glass-melting furnace that combines natural gas flames with electrical heating to transform recycled glass (cullet) and raw minerals into molten glass.
detailed_description:
A regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting is a glass melting system that combines natural gas combustion with supplementary electric heating to produce molten glass from raw materials. This hybrid configuration uses 8% electric boosting alongside air-fuel combustion, with regenerators positioned at the ends of the melting tank to recover waste heat from flue gases and preheat incoming combustion air, achieving an overall energy efficiency of approximately 70%.

The system operates by feeding cullet (recycled glass at 0.763 kt) and batch minerals (virgin raw materials at 0.244 kt) into the melting tank, where they are heated primarily by natural gas burners (3950 GJ) firing through end ports. The regenerators alternate in cycles, with one preheating combustion air using hot exhaust gases while the other discharges, significantly improving thermal efficiency. Electric boosting (392 GJ) supplements the combustion heating through electrodes submerged in the molten glass bath, providing direct resistive heating that enhances melting rates and glass quality while allowing for more precise temperature control.

The process produces 1 kt of molten glass as the main output, with 1420 GJ of energy lost through flue gases despite the heat recovery system. The regenerative air preheating reduces fuel consumption compared to non-regenerative furnaces, while the electric boosting further decreases natural gas requirements and associated carbon emissions. This technology is widely employed in container glass manufacturing, flat glass production, and specialty glass applications where high production rates, consistent glass quality, and improved environmental performance are essential requirements.

short_description: Regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting and batch/cullet preheater
laymans_description: This technology is an advanced glass-melting furnace that captures and reuses waste heat while adding electric heating for better control, and it preheats raw materials and recycled glass before they enter the main melting chamber.
detailed_description:
This technology is an advanced glass melting furnace system that combines multiple energy efficiency features to produce glass containers or flat glass products. The regenerative end-port furnace uses natural gas combustion as its primary heat source (3230 GJ) supplemented by electric boosting that provides approximately 8% additional heating capacity (329 GJ), while regenerators capture and recycle waste heat from exhaust gases to preheat incoming combustion air.

The system processes both recycled glass cullet (0.763 kt) and virgin batch minerals (0.244 kt) as raw materials. A key technical feature is the batch/cullet preheater, which uses residual heat from flue gases to warm the solid raw materials before they enter the melting furnace, significantly reducing the thermal energy required for melting. The regenerative system works by alternating airflow through ceramic checkerwork chambers that absorb heat from outgoing flue gases and transfer it to incoming combustion air, achieving thermal efficiencies typically above 50%. Electric boosting electrodes submerged in the molten glass provide supplemental heating in critical zones to maintain optimal melting temperatures and improve glass quality.

The environmental and efficiency benefits are substantial compared to conventional furnaces. By preheating both the cullet and batch minerals with waste heat recovery, the system reduces natural gas consumption by 15-25% compared to non-preheated systems. The regenerative heat exchange further improves fuel efficiency, while electric boosting allows for precise temperature control and reduces NOx emissions associated with combustion. The high cullet utilization (approximately 75% of total raw materials) decreases the energy needed for melting since recycled glass melts at lower temperatures than virgin materials, while also reducing CO2 emissions from the calcination of limestone in batch minerals.

This technology is typically applied in medium to large-scale glass manufacturing facilities producing container glass (bottles and jars), flat glass for architectural and automotive applications, and specialty glass products where consistent quality and energy efficiency are priorities.

short_description: Green gas regenerative end-port furnace with electric boosting and batch/cullet preheater
laymans_description: A glass-making furnace that uses "green gas" and electricity to melt raw materials and recycled glass, while capturing waste heat to preheat incoming materials before they enter the melting chamber.
detailed_description:
This technology is an advanced glass melting furnace that combines green gas combustion with electric boosting and waste heat recovery to produce molten glass efficiently. The system uses a regenerative end-port design where combustion air is preheated by capturing heat from exhaust gases through regenerators, which are ceramic structures that alternately absorb and release thermal energy. Electric boosting provides 8% of the total melting energy through submerged electrodes in the glass bath, allowing for more precise temperature control and reduced fuel consumption.

The furnace requires 3230 GJ of green gas (renewable methane or biogas) as the primary fuel source and 329 GJ of electricity for the boosting system. Raw materials consist of 0.763 kt of cullet (recycled glass) and 0.244 kt of batch minerals (sand, soda ash, limestone, and other additives). Both the cullet and batch minerals pass through a preheater where they absorb thermal energy from the flue gases before entering the furnace, reducing the energy required to melt them. This integrated preheating system recovers waste heat that would otherwise be lost through the stack, significantly improving overall thermal efficiency.

The environmental benefits are substantial compared to conventional furnaces. Using green gas instead of natural gas reduces carbon emissions, while the regenerative heat recovery and batch preheating system minimize overall energy consumption by recapturing and reusing thermal energy. The electric boosting further reduces fuel requirements and allows for flexible operation to match renewable electricity availability. The high cullet ratio (approximately 76% of total raw materials) reduces the energy needed for melting since recycled glass requires less thermal energy than virgin materials.

This technology is typically applied in container glass production, flat glass manufacturing, and specialty glass production facilities where environmental regulations are stringent and energy costs are significant. It is particularly suited for manufacturers committed to decarbonization goals and those operating in regions with access to renewable gas supplies and green electricity.

short_description: Oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting
laymans_description: An oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting is an advanced glass-making system that melts raw materials like cullet (recycled glass), batch minerals, and uses 3570 GJ of natural gas along with 230 GJ of electricity to produce molten glass.
detailed_description:
An oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting is an advanced glass melting technology that combines oxygen-enriched combustion with supplemental electrical heating to produce molten glass more efficiently than conventional air-fuel furnaces. The system burns natural gas (3570 GJ) with pure oxygen gas (0.285 kt) instead of atmospheric air, while electric boosting contributes additional heating energy (230 GJ), representing approximately 5% of the total energy input. This hybrid approach processes raw materials including cullet or recycled glass (0.763 kt) and batch minerals (0.244 kt) to produce molten glass (1 kt) ready for forming operations.

The technology works by introducing pure oxygen into the combustion chamber where it reacts with natural gas, creating an intensely hot flame with temperatures significantly higher than air-fuel combustion. Since oxygen replaces air, nitrogen is eliminated from the combustion process, resulting in a much smaller volume of flue gas (1820 GJ of waste heat). The electric boosting system uses submerged electrodes or other electrical heating elements to supplement the combustion heat, providing precise temperature control and additional melting capacity while reducing overall fuel consumption.

The primary environmental benefit of this technology is the dramatic reduction in flue gas volume—up to 70-80% less than conventional air-fuel furnaces—which decreases both heat losses and emissions of nitrogen oxides (NOx). The smaller exhaust volume also reduces the energy required for exhaust gas treatment and allows for more compact, efficient waste heat recovery systems. Additionally, the higher flame temperatures and more efficient heat transfer enable faster melting rates and improved glass quality with lower specific energy consumption per ton of glass produced.

This technology is typically applied in glass manufacturing industries including container glass, flat glass, and specialty glass production facilities where high-quality output and environmental compliance are priorities. It is particularly advantageous in operations requiring precise temperature control, reduced emissions to meet stringent environmental regulations, or where existing furnaces need capacity increases without physical expansion.

short_description: Oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting and electricity generation
laymans_description: This technology is an advanced glass-melting furnace that produces molten glass while recovering energy that would otherwise be wasted.
detailed_description:
An oxy-fuel furnace with electric boosting and electricity generation is an advanced glass melting system that combines oxygen-enriched combustion, supplemental electrical heating, and waste heat recovery to produce molten glass more efficiently than conventional air-fuel furnaces. The technology uses pure oxygen instead of air to combust natural gas, which eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process and results in higher flame temperatures and reduced flue gas volumes. Electric boosting supplements the combustion heating by directly introducing electrical energy through submerged electrodes in the glass melt, providing precise temperature control and additional melting capacity.

The process operates by feeding batch minerals and cullet (recycled glass) into the furnace where they are melted using 3570 GJ of natural gas burned with 0.285 kt of oxygen gas, supplemented by 67.8 GJ of electricity for boosting. The combination of 0.763 kt cullet and 0.244 kt batch minerals produces 1 kt of molten glass as the primary output. A key feature of this system is the integration of heat recovery equipment that captures residual thermal energy from the 199 GJ of flue gas exiting the furnace, which can be converted back into electricity for on-site use or export to the grid.

This technology offers significant environmental benefits including reduced CO2 emissions due to lower fuel consumption compared to air-fuel systems, elimination of nitrogen oxides (NOx) formation from atmospheric nitrogen, and improved energy efficiency through waste heat recovery. The smaller flue gas volume also reduces particulate emissions and simplifies pollution control equipment requirements.

Typical industrial applications include container glass manufacturing, flat glass production, specialty glass fabrication, and fiberglass manufacturing where high-quality melting, fuel efficiency, and emission control are critical operational requirements. The technology is particularly suitable for large-scale continuous melting operations where the capital investment can be justified by long-term energy savings and environmental compliance benefits.

short_description: Oxy/fuel furnace with bubblers and electricity generation
laymans_description: This technology is an advanced glass manufacturing furnace that melts recycled glass (cullet) and raw materials (batch minerals) into molten glass while also generating electricity from waste heat.
detailed_description:
An oxy-fuel furnace with bubblers and electricity generation is an advanced glass melting system that uses pure oxygen instead of air for combustion while incorporating bubble technology to enhance melting efficiency and recovering waste heat for power generation. The primary purpose is to produce molten glass while minimizing energy consumption and generating electricity from exhaust heat that would otherwise be lost to the atmosphere.

The system operates by combusting natural gas (3580 GJ) with pure oxygen gas (0.285 kt) rather than air, which eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process and results in higher flame temperatures and more efficient heat transfer. Bubbling technology injects gases through submerged ports in the molten glass bath, creating turbulence that accelerates melting and homogenization of the raw materials. The furnace processes cullet or recycled glass (0.763 kt) and batch minerals (0.244 kt) to produce 1 kt of molten glass, while requiring 58.7 GJ of electricity for auxiliary equipment like oxygen supply systems, bubblers, and control systems. Downstream heat recovery equipment captures thermal energy from the flue gas (199 GJ), converting it to electricity through steam turbines or organic Rankine cycle systems, offsetting some of the facility's electrical demand.

This technology offers significant environmental benefits including reduced NOx emissions due to the absence of nitrogen in combustion, lower overall energy consumption per ton of glass produced, and improved thermal efficiency through waste heat recovery for electricity generation. The reduced flue gas volume compared to air-fuel systems also decreases particulate emissions and simplifies pollution control equipment requirements.

Typical applications include container glass manufacturing, flat glass production, and specialty glass facilities where high-quality melting, energy efficiency, and environmental performance are priorities, particularly in regions with strict emissions regulations or high energy costs.

short_description: Oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting and air/NG/cullet preheater
laymans_description: This technology is an advanced glass-making furnace that melts raw materials like recycled glass (cullet) and minerals into molten glass more efficiently than traditional furnaces.
detailed_description:
This technology is an advanced glass melting furnace system that combines oxy-fuel combustion with electric boosting and integrated heat recovery through preheating. The primary purpose is to melt raw materials (cullet and batch minerals) efficiently to produce molten glass while maximizing energy utilization and reducing emissions compared to conventional air-fuel furnaces.

The system operates by combusting natural gas (2940 GJ) with pure oxygen gas (0.234 kt) instead of atmospheric air, which eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process and produces a more concentrated, higher-temperature flame. Electric boosting contributes an additional 198 GJ of energy directly into the melt, providing approximately 5% of the total energy input and enhancing melting efficiency. A critical efficiency feature is the integrated preheating system that recovers heat from flue gases to preheat the cullet (recycled glass at 0.763 kt), which in turn transfers this thermal energy to the batch minerals (0.244 kt) during the melting process. This cascading heat recovery approach ensures maximum utilization of available thermal energy before gases exit the system.

The environmental and efficiency benefits are substantial, as oxy-fuel combustion produces significantly lower NOx emissions due to the absence of nitrogen, generates smaller volumes of flue gas that are more CO2-concentrated (facilitating potential carbon capture), and achieves higher thermal efficiency through the preheating systems. The reduced flue gas volume (199 GJ leaving the system) demonstrates effective heat recovery, as much of the combustion energy is retained within the process rather than lost to exhaust.

This technology is typically applied in glass manufacturing facilities producing container glass, flat glass, and specialty glass products where high-quality molten glass production is required with stringent environmental controls and energy cost considerations.

short_description: Green gas oxy/fuel furnace with electric boosting and air/NG/cullet preheater
laymans_description: This is an industrial furnace that melts recycled glass and raw materials more efficiently by burning renewable gas with pure oxygen instead of air, using waste heat to preheat materials, and adding some electric heating to boost the process.
detailed_description:
This technology is an advanced glass melting furnace system that combines oxy-fuel combustion with electric boosting and integrated heat recovery for preheating materials. The primary purpose is to efficiently melt glass raw materials while minimizing energy consumption and emissions through the use of renewable green gas instead of conventional natural gas, alongside oxygen-enriched combustion that produces cleaner, more concentrated flue gases.

The furnace operates by combusting green gas with pure oxygen rather than atmospheric air, which eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process and significantly increases flame temperatures while reducing flue gas volumes. Electric boosting provides 5% of the total melting energy through electrodes immersed in the molten glass, offering precise temperature control and supplementary heating. The system incorporates a sophisticated heat recovery mechanism where hot flue gases preheat the cullet (recycled glass), which then serves as a thermal carrier to heat the batch minerals when mixed together, creating a cascading heat transfer effect that maximizes energy utilization.

The process requires 2940 GJ of green gas as the primary fuel source, 198 GJ of electricity for boosting, 0.234 kt of oxygen gas for combustion, 0.763 kt of cullet, and 0.244 kt of batch minerals as feedstock materials. These inputs produce molten glass ready for forming operations while generating significantly lower emissions compared to conventional air-fuel furnaces.

Environmental benefits include substantial CO2 reduction through the use of renewable green gas, decreased NOx emissions due to oxygen combustion eliminating atmospheric nitrogen, reduced particulate emissions, and improved overall thermal efficiency through integrated preheating systems. This technology is particularly valuable in container glass manufacturing, flat glass production, and specialty glass applications where high-quality melting with reduced environmental impact is essential for meeting increasingly stringent regulatory requirements and sustainability targets.

short_description: Post-melting process CG
laymans_description: Post-melting process CG is a manufacturing technique used after metal or other materials have been melted and initially formed, applying additional controlled treatments to improve the final product's quality and properties.
detailed_description:
Post-melting process CG is a comprehensive glass manufacturing process that transforms molten glass into finished container glass products through a series of sequential steps: refining, forming, annealing, surface treatment, and inspection. This process handles the downstream operations after the primary melting stage, representing approximately 19% of total energy consumption in glass manufacturing facilities, with the remaining energy distributed between the melting furnace (80%) and batch mixing (1%).

The process begins with 1.07 kilotons of molten glass feed and requires 542 GJ of natural gas and 482 GJ of electricity to complete all post-melting operations. Natural gas accounts for 53% of the post-melting energy demand and is primarily used for maintaining temperature during forming operations and the critical annealing process, where glass is carefully cooled to relieve internal stresses. Electricity powers the remaining 47% of operations, including mechanical forming equipment, surface treatment systems, and automated inspection machinery. The refining step removes bubbles and homogenizes the glass, followed by forming where the glass is shaped into containers, then annealing in controlled-temperature lehrs to prevent cracking, and finally surface treatments to enhance strength and facilitate labeling.

This technology offers environmental benefits through its relatively balanced energy profile, utilizing both natural gas and electricity which allows flexibility in energy sourcing and potential integration of renewable electricity. The specific energy distribution reflects modern efficiency standards where electric boosting and automation reduce overall fossil fuel consumption compared to traditional all-gas processes. Container glass manufacturing for beverage bottles, food jars, and pharmaceutical containers represents the primary industrial application, where this post-melting process is essential for producing high-quality, durable glass products that meet stringent safety and performance standards.

short_description: Green gas regenerative furnace with electric boosting
laymans_description: This technology is an industrial furnace that uses renewable "green" gas as its primary fuel while capturing and reusing waste heat through a regenerative system, with supplemental electric heating when needed.
detailed_description:
A green gas regenerative furnace with electric boosting is an advanced glass melting system that uses biomethane (green gas) as its primary fuel source instead of conventional natural gas, while supplementing heating capacity with electric boosting elements. This technology enables glass manufacturers to significantly reduce carbon emissions while maintaining high-quality production standards using existing furnace infrastructure without requiring major refurbishments to the burner systems.

The furnace operates by combusting biomethane in gas burners integrated with a regenerative heat recovery system that preheats incoming combustion air using waste heat from exhaust gases, improving thermal efficiency. Electric boosting elements submerged in the molten glass bath provide supplementary heating, using 392 GJ of electricity alongside 3950 GJ of green gas to achieve the precise temperatures required for melting. The furnace processes 0.763 kt of cullet (recycled glass) and 0.244 kt of batch minerals (primarily silica sand, soda ash, and limestone), melting these raw materials into homogeneous molten glass at temperatures exceeding 1500°C.

The environmental benefits of this technology are substantial, as biomethane is considered carbon-neutral since it is derived from organic waste sources, dramatically reducing the carbon footprint compared to fossil natural gas. The regenerative heat recovery system achieves energy efficiency rates of 50-60%, while the incorporation of cullet reduces the energy required for melting and decreases raw material consumption. The electric boosting component provides operational flexibility and can further reduce emissions when powered by renewable electricity sources.

This technology finds typical applications in container glass manufacturing, flat glass production, and specialty glass industries where high-volume continuous melting operations are standard. It is particularly valuable for manufacturers seeking to meet stringent emissions regulations and sustainability targets while maintaining production capacity and glass quality without the capital expense and operational disruption of complete furnace replacement.

short_description: Thermally efficient furnace which relies on electricity for replacing air/ful or oxy/fuel furnace
laymans_description: An electric cold-top furnace is a highly energy-efficient glass-making system that uses electricity instead of traditional fuel-burning methods to melt raw materials into molten glass.
detailed_description:
The electric cold-top furnace is an advanced glassmaking technology that uses electrical resistance heating as the primary energy source for melting glass, completely replacing conventional air/fuel or oxy/fuel combustion systems. The technology employs submerged electrodes that pass electric current directly through the glass batch, generating heat through electrical resistance within the molten glass itself. This "cold-top" design maintains a layer of unmelted batch material on the surface, which acts as thermal insulation to reduce heat losses and improve energy efficiency.

The furnace requires three key inputs to produce molten glass: electricity at 4160 GJ, cullet (recycled glass) at 0.5 kt, and batch minerals at 0.5 kt. The cullet and batch minerals are fed into the furnace where the submerged electrodes provide resistive heating to melt these raw materials, producing 1 kt of molten glass as the output. The electrical heating is more controllable and uniform compared to flame-based heating, allowing for precise temperature management throughout the melting process.

This technology offers significant environmental benefits by eliminating direct combustion emissions, including NOx, SOx, and particulate matter that are typically associated with fossil fuel-fired furnaces. The thermal efficiency is substantially higher because energy is delivered directly to the melt rather than through radiant heat transfer, and the insulating cold-top layer minimizes heat escape. Electric cold-top furnaces are particularly well-suited for specialty glass production, container glass manufacturing, and fiber glass applications where product quality, emission control, and energy efficiency are critical considerations.

short_description: Advanced heat recovery for oxy/fuel fired glass furnaces, where the input gas is converted into a hot syngas, applied...
laymans_description: OPTIMELT TCR Plus CG is an advanced glass manufacturing system that efficiently produces molten container glass by melting down a combination of recycled glass (cullet) and new raw materials (batch minerals) using an innovative heat recovery process.
detailed_description:
OPTIMELT TCR Plus CG is an advanced glass melting technology designed for container glass production that integrates thermal chemical recuperation (TCR) with oxy-fuel combustion to significantly improve energy efficiency. The system converts natural gas into hot syngas through a heat recovery process, utilizing the waste heat from the furnace flue gases to reform the fuel before combustion, thereby maximizing thermal efficiency in the melting process.

The technology operates by feeding natural gas (3000 GJ) and oxygen (0.258 kt) into an oxy-fuel furnace, eliminating nitrogen from the combustion atmosphere to reduce thermal losses and increase flame temperatures. The furnace melts a combination of recycled cullet (0.763 kt, representing approximately 75% of the raw material input) and fresh batch minerals (0.244 kt) to produce molten glass. Electric boosting provides an additional 210 GJ of energy, contributing roughly 7% of the total energy input to enhance melting rates and temperature control. The oxygen preheating feature ("Plus") further improves efficiency by recovering heat from the flue gases to warm the oxygen before it enters the combustion chamber.

This system delivers significant environmental benefits through reduced energy consumption and lower CO2 emissions compared to conventional air-fuel furnaces, with flue gas losses minimized to just 328 GJ from the total 3210 GJ energy input. The high cullet rate capability reduces the need for virgin raw materials and their associated processing energy, while the oxy-fuel combustion produces a more concentrated CO2 stream that could facilitate future carbon capture integration. The technology produces 1 kt of molten glass output, making it particularly suitable for container glass manufacturing facilities seeking to optimize energy efficiency while maintaining high production rates and glass quality.

short_description: Advanced heat recovery for oxy/fuel fired glass furnaces, where the input gas is converted into a hot syngas
laymans_description: The OPTIMELT TCR technology is an energy-efficient glass melting system specifically designed for producing tableware like plates, bowls, and drinking glasses.
detailed_description:
OPTIMELT TCR (Total Combustion Regeneration) is an advanced glass melting technology designed for tableware production that uses oxy-fuel combustion combined with sophisticated heat recovery. The system converts natural gas feedstock into a hot syngas before combustion, allowing it to capture and reuse waste heat that would otherwise be lost through the flue gas in conventional furnaces. This technology is specifically configured for tableware manufacturing with a 50% cullet (recycled glass) rate and incorporates 5% electric boosting to optimize melting efficiency.

The process operates by feeding 3840 GJ of natural gas along with 0.307 kt of gaseous oxygen into the system, where the fuel undergoes conversion to syngas at elevated temperatures before final combustion. The melting operation combines 0.5 kt of cullet with 0.5 kt of batch minerals (raw materials like silica, soda ash, and limestone), using the intense heat from oxy-fuel combustion to melt these materials. An additional 244 GJ of electricity is supplied for electric boosting, which helps maintain precise temperature control and accelerates the melting process. The system produces 1 kt of molten glass as its main output while generating 865 GJ of flue gas.

The primary environmental benefit of OPTIMELT TCR lies in its exceptional fuel efficiency through heat regeneration, significantly reducing natural gas consumption compared to conventional air-fired furnaces. The oxy-fuel combustion produces a more concentrated flue gas stream with less nitrogen dilution, making the flue gas heat more valuable for recovery and the exhaust volume smaller. This translates to lower CO2 emissions per ton of glass produced and reduced overall energy costs for manufacturers.

This technology is particularly suited for high-quality tableware production where precise temperature control and glass quality are paramount, including applications in crystal glassware, decorative glass items, and premium dining products. The system's ability to accommodate high cullet rates also makes it attractive for manufacturers seeking to increase recycled content in their products while maintaining production efficiency.

short_description: Advanced heat recovery for oxy/fuel fired glass furnaces, where the input gas (green gas) is converted into a hot syn...
laymans_description: The Green gas OPTIMELT TCR Plus CG is an advanced glass manufacturing system that produces molten glass while recovering and reusing heat energy that would otherwise be wasted.
detailed_description:
The Green gas OPTIMELT TCR Plus CG is an advanced glass melting technology that converts green gas (renewable methane or biogas) into syngas within a thermochemical regenerator (TCR) while recovering waste heat from oxy-fuel fired furnaces used in container glass production. The system utilizes oxygen-enhanced combustion instead of air, which produces higher flame temperatures and more concentrated flue gas streams, enabling efficient heat recovery. The "Plus" designation indicates the inclusion of oxygen preheating capabilities, which further improves thermal efficiency.

The process operates by feeding 3000 GJ of green gas along with 0.258 kt of oxygen into the furnace system, where the TCR converts the green gas into hot syngas by capturing heat from exhaust gases. This syngas then serves as the primary fuel for melting a mixture of 0.763 kt of cullet (recycled glass) and 0.244 kt of batch minerals (raw materials like silica and soda ash). The high cullet rate of approximately 76% significantly reduces the energy required for melting since recycled glass has a lower melting point than raw materials. Electric boosting at 10% of total energy input (210 GJ) provides supplementary heating and precise temperature control, ensuring consistent glass quality while producing 1 kt of molten glass.

This technology delivers substantial environmental benefits by utilizing renewable green gas as the primary fuel source and incorporating a high percentage of recycled cullet, both of which dramatically reduce CO2 emissions compared to conventional natural gas furnaces with lower cullet rates. The thermochemical regeneration process recovers 328 GJ of energy in the flue gas, representing approximately 11% of input energy that can potentially be used for preheating oxygen or other auxiliary processes. The oxy-fuel combustion eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process, resulting in higher efficiency and reduced NOx emissions.

The technology is primarily applied in container glass manufacturing for products such as bottles and jars, where high production volumes and quality consistency are essential. It is particularly suitable for glass manufacturers seeking to decarbonize operations while maintaining competitive production costs, especially in regions with access to renewable gas supplies and robust glass recycling infrastructure.

short_description: Advanced heat recovery for oxy/fuel fired glass furnaces, where the input gas (green gas) is converted into a hot syngas
laymans_description: The OPTIMELT TCR technology is an advanced glass manufacturing system that produces molten glass for tableware items like plates and bowls by efficiently converting green gas fuel into hot syngas while recovering waste heat from the furnace.
detailed_description:
The Green gas OPTIMELT TCR technology is an advanced glass melting system designed for tableware production that combines thermal chemical recuperation (TCR) with oxy-fuel combustion. The system converts incoming green gas (renewable methane or biogas) into hot syngas through a heat recovery process that captures waste heat from the furnace flue gases, effectively preheating and chemically upgrading the fuel before combustion. This endothermic reforming reaction improves overall energy efficiency by recovering thermal energy that would otherwise be lost in conventional furnaces.

The process operates by melting a mixture of 50% recycled glass cullet (0.5 kt) and 50% virgin batch minerals (0.5 kt) using oxy-fuel burners supplied with pure oxygen gas (0.307 kt) rather than air. The green gas (3840 GJ) serves as the primary fuel source, while electricity (244 GJ) provides approximately 5% electric boosting through electrodes immersed in the molten glass bath, which helps maintain precise temperature control and melting efficiency. The oxygen-enriched combustion eliminates nitrogen from the flame, resulting in higher flame temperatures and more efficient heat transfer to the glass melt.

This technology delivers significant environmental benefits by utilizing renewable green gas as the primary energy source and incorporating substantial recycled content through cullet usage, reducing both fossil fuel consumption and raw material extraction. The TCR heat recovery mechanism substantially reduces overall energy consumption compared to conventional air-fuel glass furnaces, while the reduced flue gas volume (865 GJ of waste heat) minimizes stack losses and potentially enables more compact pollution control equipment.

The OPTIMELT TCR system is particularly suited for high-quality tableware glass production where precise temperature control and glass quality are paramount, and can be applied across various container and specialty glass manufacturing operations seeking to decarbonize their melting processes while maintaining production efficiency and product quality standards.

short_description: Advanced heat recovery for oxy/fuel fired glass furnaces, where the input gas is converted into a hot syngas
laymans_description: OPTIMELT TCR Plus Tableware is an advanced glass-melting technology that produces molten glass for tableware items like plates and cups while recovering and reusing heat that would otherwise be wasted.
detailed_description:
OPTIMELT TCR Plus Tableware is an advanced glass melting technology designed for producing tableware glass in oxy-fuel fired furnaces with integrated heat recovery and syngas conversion. The system converts natural gas feedstock into hot syngas while recovering waste heat, enabling more efficient glass production compared to conventional air-fuel melting systems. This technology is specifically configured for tableware manufacturing facilities requiring high-quality molten glass output.

The process operates by consuming 3560 GJ of natural gas and 240 GJ of electricity (representing 10% electric boosting) to melt raw materials consisting of 0.5 kt of cullet (recycled glass) and 0.5 kt of batch minerals, achieving a 50% cullet rate. The system utilizes 0.284 kt of gaseous oxygen for oxy-fuel combustion, which produces higher flame temperatures and eliminates nitrogen from the combustion process. A key technical feature is the preheating of oxygen and the conversion of input natural gas into hot syngas, which enhances heat transfer efficiency within the furnace. The melting process generates 1 kt of molten glass as the primary product while exhausting 389 GJ of energy in flue gases.

The technology offers significant environmental and efficiency benefits through its advanced heat recovery system, which captures and reuses thermal energy that would otherwise be lost. The oxy-fuel combustion combined with syngas conversion substantially reduces flue gas volumes compared to air-fuel systems, leading to lower energy consumption per ton of glass produced and reduced carbon emissions. The high cullet incorporation rate (50%) further enhances sustainability by recycling glass waste and reducing the energy required for melting virgin materials.

This technology is particularly suited for high-quality tableware glass production in industrial settings where energy efficiency and environmental performance are priorities, including manufacturing of dinnerware, drinking glasses, and decorative glass items that require precise temperature control and consistent melt quality.

short_description: Removal of particulates/contaminants/water from the flue gases and CO2 compression into a sealed container
laymans_description: This post-combustion carbon capture system takes waste carbon dioxide from industrial exhaust gases and prepares it for safe storage by cleaning and compressing it into a transportable form.
detailed_description:
A post-combustion carbon capture and storage (CCS) system for oxyfuel furnaces is designed to remove and compress carbon dioxide from industrial flue gas streams before atmospheric release. The system processes approximately 1.02 kilotonnes of CO2 from combustion exhaust, treating it through purification stages that eliminate particulates, contaminants, and water vapor, ultimately compressing the purified CO2 into a transportable, sealed form suitable for storage or utilization applications.

The technology operates by first capturing CO2-rich flue gas from oxyfuel combustion processes, where fuel burns in an oxygen-enriched environment rather than air, producing higher CO2 concentrations. The captured gas undergoes multi-stage treatment including filtration and dehydration to remove impurities that could compromise compression equipment or storage integrity. The system requires 2,750 GJ of natural gas to provide process heat for gas conditioning and regeneration of capture media, while 1,830 GJ of electricity powers compressors that pressurize the purified CO2 to approximately 100-150 bar, transforming it into a dense, supercritical or liquid state. This compression process accounts for the majority of the electrical demand, as the CO2 must reach sufficient pressure for pipeline transport or geological injection.

The primary output is approximately 1 kilotonne of compressed CO2, representing roughly 98% recovery of the input stream, with minor losses occurring during purification stages. From an environmental perspective, this technology prevents nearly all processed CO2 from entering the atmosphere, offering carbon capture rates exceeding 90% compared to unabated industrial processes. The energy penalty—the additional energy required for capture and compression—is partially offset by the high-purity CO2 stream produced in oxyfuel systems, which requires less separation work than traditional post-combustion capture from air-fired furnaces.

Typical industrial applications include cement manufacturing, steel production, glass melting, and large-scale power generation facilities where oxyfuel combustion can be integrated with existing furnace infrastructure. Industries with high-temperature process requirements particularly benefit from this approach, as the oxyfuel configuration enables both efficient combustion and concentrated CO2 production suitable for capture.

short_description: Refining, Forming, Annealing, Surface treatment, Inspection
laymans_description: This technology takes molten glass and transforms it into finished tableware products like plates, bowls, and drinking glasses through a series of post-melting processes including refining (removing impurities), forming (shaping the glass), annealing (controlled cooling to strengthen it), surface treatment, and quality inspection.
detailed_description:
The post-melting process for tableware glass encompasses the finishing stages that transform molten glass into final consumer products, including refining, forming, annealing, surface treatment, and inspection. This process represents approximately 29% of the total energy consumption in tableware glass manufacturing, with the remaining energy used primarily in the melting furnace (70%) and batch mixing (1%). The purpose is to shape, strengthen, and finish molten glass into high-quality tableware items suitable for commercial sale.

The process operates with a specific energy split of 65% natural gas and 35% electricity within the post-melting stages. The natural gas (1090 GJ) primarily fuels the annealing lehrs that slowly cool the formed glass to relieve internal stresses and prevent cracking, while electricity (584 GJ) powers forming equipment, surface treatment systems, and inspection machinery. The process begins with 1.07 kilotonnes of molten glass feed and produces 1 kilotonne of finished glass product, representing a 6.5% material loss due to trimming, quality rejection, and breakage during handling.

From an efficiency perspective, this post-melting configuration demonstrates optimized energy distribution by leveraging natural gas for high-temperature annealing processes where continuous heat is most cost-effective, while using electricity for precision operations requiring controlled power delivery. The 93.5% material yield rate reflects modern quality control and forming efficiency, minimizing waste generation. Typical industrial applications include manufacturing drinking glasses, dinner plates, bowls, serving dishes, and other household tableware items where consistent quality, durability, and aesthetic finish are critical market requirements.

short_description: Method of pre-processing iron ore for the blast furnace
laymans_description: A sinter plant is a facility that prepares iron ore for use in blast furnaces by transforming fine iron ore particles into larger, more usable chunks through a heating and fusion process.
detailed_description:
A sinter plant is a pre-processing facility that agglomerates fine iron ore particles into a porous, clinker-like material called sinter, which serves as the primary feedstock for blast furnaces in steelmaking. The technology addresses the challenge that fine iron ore particles cannot be directly charged into blast furnaces due to poor gas permeability and tendency to be blown out with exhaust gases. By converting these fines into larger, more permeable pieces, sinter plants enable efficient blast furnace operation while utilizing lower-cost fine ore materials.

The sintering process works by mixing iron ore fines (0.8 Mt) with calcium carbonate (0.18 Mt) as a flux and a small amount of coke (0.04 Mt) as fuel. This mixture is spread onto a moving grate where ignition occurs at the surface, and combustion progresses downward through the bed. Natural gas (0.04 PJ) assists in the ignition process, while electricity (0.124 PJ) powers the ventilation fans that draw air through the bed, sustaining combustion and fusing the particles together. The process produces approximately 1 Mt of sinter from 0.8 Mt of iron ore input, with the mass increase due to the incorporation of flux materials.

Sinter plants provide significant efficiency benefits by enabling the use of fine iron ore that would otherwise require pelletizing or be unsuitable for blast furnaces. The technology reduces overall energy consumption in steelmaking by pre-reducing some iron oxides and incorporating flux materials before the blast furnace stage, thereby lowering coke requirements downstream. Additionally, sinter's porous structure improves gas flow in blast furnaces, enhancing reduction efficiency and productivity. This technology is standard in integrated steel mills worldwide, particularly those using blast furnace-basic oxygen furnace routes, and is essential for modern iron and steel production where fine ore concentrates dominate the raw material supply.

short_description: Method of pre-processing iron ore for the blast furnace
laymans_description: A pellet plant is a facility that transforms raw iron ore into compact, uniform pellets that are easier and more efficient to use in blast furnaces for steel production.
detailed_description:
A pellet plant is an iron ore pre-processing facility that transforms fine iron ore particles into uniformly sized, hardened spherical pellets suitable for use in blast furnaces. The pelletization process improves the permeability and reducibility of iron ore in subsequent steelmaking operations, making it more efficient than using raw fine ore directly. This technology serves as a critical intermediate step in the iron and steel production chain, converting low-grade or fine iron ore materials into a premium feedstock.

The process begins with 1.08 Mt of iron ore being ground, mixed with small quantities of binding agents (olivine at 0.0231 kt and calcium carbonate at 0.0147 kt), and formed into green pellets through agglomeration. These pellets are then hardened through high-temperature treatment using multiple energy sources: BOFG (Blast Furnace Off-Gas) at 0.231 PJ provides the primary thermal energy, supplemented by natural gas at 0.00839 PJ and a minimal amount of coke (0.00839 Mt) as fuel. The process also requires 0.0765 PJ of electricity to power grinding mills, pelletizing discs, and material handling equipment. The result is 1 Mt of high-quality iron ore pellets with improved physical and chemical properties.

Pelletization offers significant environmental and efficiency benefits by enabling the use of fine ore materials that would otherwise be difficult to process in blast furnaces, reducing waste and extending ore resource utilization. The uniform size and composition of pellets improve blast furnace performance by enhancing gas flow and heat distribution, leading to reduced coke consumption and lower emissions in downstream steelmaking. This technology is widely employed in integrated steel mills worldwide, particularly in regions with abundant fine iron ore deposits, and is essential for modern iron production facilities seeking to optimize their raw material preparation and overall process efficiency.

short_description: Method of pre-processing iron ore for the blast furnace
laymans_description: A pellet plant transforms raw iron ore into compact, uniform pellets that are easier and more efficient to use in blast furnaces for steelmaking.
detailed_description:
A pellet plant without coke production is an ore beneficiation facility that converts fine iron ore particles into uniformly-sized, hardened spherical pellets suitable for use in blast furnaces or direct reduction processes. This technology addresses the challenge of utilizing fine iron ore concentrates that cannot be directly charged into furnaces due to poor permeability and handling characteristics. The process transforms approximately 1.08 million tonnes of fine iron ore into 1 million tonnes of consolidated pellets with improved metallurgical properties.

The pelletization process begins with grinding and mixing the iron ore with small quantities of binding agents (olivine at 23.1 tonnes and calcium carbonate at 14.7 tonnes) that serve as fluxing materials to control pellet chemistry and basicity. The mixture is then formed into green pellets through rolling drum or disc pelletizers, which agglomerate the fine particles into spheres typically 9-16mm in diameter. These green pellets are subsequently fired in induration furnaces using natural gas (0.239 PJ) and coal (8,390 tonnes) as primary fuels, along with electricity (0.0765 PJ) for auxiliary equipment, reaching temperatures of 1200-1350°C to achieve the necessary hardness and strength through oxidation and sintering of iron oxide particles.

The resulting iron ore pellets offer several advantages over lump ore or sinter, including uniform size distribution, high iron content, consistent quality, and superior reducibility in the blast furnace. The relatively compact nature of this process, which excludes coke production, results in lower capital investment and reduced environmental footprint compared to integrated facilities. These pellets are primarily used in steelmaking operations, particularly in blast furnaces where their uniform properties improve furnace permeability and productivity, and in direct reduction plants where their porosity enhances gas-solid reactions during the reduction process.

short_description: Method of pre-processing coal for the blast furnace
laymans_description: A coke plant is a facility that transforms regular coal into coke, a purified form of carbon that's essential for making steel in blast furnaces.
detailed_description:
A coke plant is an industrial facility that thermally processes coal through destructive distillation to produce coke, a porous, carbon-rich solid fuel essential for blast furnace operations in steelmaking. The primary purpose is to convert coal into a stronger, more energy-dense material with reduced impurities and volatiles that can withstand the physical and thermal stresses inside a blast furnace while providing both heat and a reducing agent for iron ore.

The process operates by heating coal (36.7 PJ input) in oxygen-deprived ovens at temperatures around 1000-1100°C, driving off volatile compounds through carbonization. The facility uses supplemental energy from coke oven gas (COG, 2.68 PJ), blast furnace gas (BFG, 0.818 PJ), electricity (0.136 PJ), and medium-pressure steam (0.43 PJ) to maintain the high temperatures required and power auxiliary systems. During carbonization, volatile matter is released and captured, then processed to recover valuable byproducts including additional coke oven gas (7.23 PJ output), coal tar (35.9 kt), and benzene-toluene-xylene compounds known as BTX (11.8 kt). The main output is 1 Mt of metallurgical coke, while the process also generates 1.5 PJ of medium-pressure steam from waste heat recovery.

The technology offers significant efficiency benefits through energy integration, as the COG produced exceeds the amount consumed as input, creating a net energy surplus that can fuel the coke ovens themselves or be used elsewhere in the integrated steel mill. Recovery of chemical byproducts like tar and BTX prevents waste and creates additional revenue streams, while steam generation from waste heat improves overall thermal efficiency. Coke plants are integral to integrated steel mills worldwide, particularly those using traditional blast furnace-basic oxygen furnace routes, and the byproducts find applications in chemical manufacturing, pharmaceuticals, and as industrial fuels.

short_description: Production of pig iron
laymans_description: A blast furnace is a massive industrial tower that produces pig iron, the primary ingredient for making steel, by chemically extracting pure iron from iron-containing materials through an intense heating process.
detailed_description:
A blast furnace is a large-scale metallurgical reactor designed to produce pig iron, the primary feedstock for steelmaking, through the chemical reduction of iron oxides. The process operates continuously at extremely high temperatures (up to 2000°C) where iron-bearing materials are converted into molten iron through reduction reactions with carbon-based fuels. The blast furnace represents the dominant iron production method globally, processing approximately 1.4 million tonnes of iron-bearing inputs (including 0.6 Mt sinter, 0.75 Mt iron ore pellets, and 0.04 Mt direct iron ore) to produce 1 Mt of pig iron.

The process requires substantial energy inputs totaling approximately 9.9 PJ, primarily from coal (7.54 PJ) as the main reducing agent and fuel source, supplemented by coke (0.32 Mt), which provides structural support and additional carbon. The furnace also utilizes recycled blast furnace gas or BFG (1.41 PJ), coke oven gas or COG (0.27 PJ), natural gas (0.16 PJ), and smaller amounts of oil (0.03 PJ), steam (0.23 PJ), and electricity (0.27 PJ) for auxiliary operations. Oxygen injection (52.6 kt) enhances combustion efficiency and allows for increased production rates while reducing coke consumption. Hot air or "blast" is blown through tuyeres near the furnace bottom, creating a counter-current flow where ascending hot gases reduce descending iron oxides in a multi-stage process.

The technology generates two primary outputs beyond the main pig iron product: blast furnace slag (0.22 Mt), a byproduct that can be processed into cement or construction materials, and blast furnace gas (5.14 PJ), which is cleaned and recycled as fuel within the integrated steel mill. This gas recycling provides significant environmental benefits by recovering approximately 52% of the input energy, reducing overall fossil fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions per tonne of iron produced. The slag utilization further enhances resource efficiency by converting waste material into valuable industrial products.
